title: My Identity as an Adult With Asthma

content: My identity as someone living with asthma has transitioned from one of embarrassment and shame to informed and empowered.

To be honest, as a kid, I thought having asthma was cool. Watching kids with asthma on movies and TV shows seemed intriguing. Here’s this kid that gets to stop in the middle of playing, take a deep drag on a cool-looking device, and get all the attention! As a bit of a ham, I guess I thought it was a party trick of sorts. I didn’t know anyone with asthma, so I didn’t truly understand how dangerous it could be.

It’s amazing how your view of something as a kid can be so much different from reality. I went through my childhood years without anything close to an asthma attack. I had scarlet fever as a child that impacted my breathing a bit, but the memories of that are hazy. In general, I was a healthy child with just the occasional cold or sore throat. I never broke a bone, never had an ER visit, and didn’t have surgery until I was in my mid-30s.

sections.heading: When Things Got Real
content: During my college and early adult years, I found myself coming down with bronchitis several times a year. Each time, it seemed to take me longer and longer to recover. Bottles of empty cough medicine would sit on my dresser along with antibiotics, supplements, and anything else I could get my hands on to provide relief.

There were times my cough was so bad, I would gag and even throw up. Still, I thought perhaps I was just one of those folks who take longer to recover from illness. I did my best to stay healthy, but somehow, I would not be able to avoid the “bronchitis blues” several times each winter and at least once each spring.

When I changed doctors, and she informed me that what I was really dealing with was adult-onset asthma , I was shocked and scared. By this time, I knew about the dangers of asthma and how it could limit your quality of life. It was the last thing I wanted to hear. I was known as an active young woman who loved to dance, hike, and travel. An asthma diagnosis seemed like it would be life-changing and the end of everything that made me -- me. Would I be the same person I had been for the past 20 years?

sections.heading: Scarlet Letter ‘A’
content: After my diagnosis, I was in denial for a few months. I thought I could perhaps continue life as normal under the radar with no one knowing I had asthma. Here I was, a full adult with a condition that I always assumed was only diagnosed in children. It wasn't too long after my diagnosis, however, that I saw it would be nearly impossible to hide. Early on, my doctor prescribed a rescue inhaler to be used as needed. My secret was safe until I started Zumba classes and would often need to take a puff before or during workouts. Can we say embarrassing!? When friends and family would ask me why it was taking me so long to get over a cold, I eventually had to tell them about my asthma and how it was contributing to my symptoms. No matter how I tried to hide, I felt like a big letter “A” for “asthma” was on my forehead, and I didn’t like it.

sections.heading: Today’s New Attitude
content: It took me years to fully accept my asthma diagnosis and to be completely candid with my doctors about my symptoms. No, I don't list my asthma as a fun fact during Zoom icebreakers, nor do I include it in my standard introduction when I meet fellow dog lovers at the park. I do, however, recognize that I need to make certain modifications to be healthy with asthma. I no longer downplay my symptoms with my doctors. I take my medication (now a daily inhaler) as prescribed, and I make slight modifications to my exercise and travel routines as needed. Many of my peers and family members deal with some type of health condition. Mine happens to be asthma, and I'm going to make the best of it.
